docs.snippet: LEAD: The Houston summit conference was a successful holding operation. In the face of conflicts over aid to the Soviet Union, the elimination of agricultural subsidies and actions to deal with environmental pollution and global warming, the leaders...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Houston summit conference was a successful holding operation. In the face of conflicts over aid to the Soviet Union, the elimination of agricultural subsidies and actions to deal with environmental pollution and global warming, the leaders of the seven major industrial countries preserved their civility and produced a set of compromises that will enable them to go on working together a while longer.

headline.main: Economic Scene;   Deep Divisions At Summit Talks

docs.snippet: LEAD:    TENNIS       Wilander Beaten in Second Round       Mats Wilander's comeback suffered a setback yesterday when the Swede was beaten by Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-2, 3-6, 7-6, in the second round of the Swedish Open in Bastad. Wilander,...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TENNIS Wilander Beaten in Second Round Mats Wilander's comeback suffered a setback yesterday when the Swede was beaten by Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay, 6-2, 3-6, 7-6, in the second round of the Swedish Open in Bastad. Wilander, ranked No. 1 in the world before slipping and then taking a five-month break, made several unforced errors in losing the third-set tie breaker.

docs.snippet: LEAD:    TENNIS       Sabatini to Meet Grossman: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and Ann Grossman of the United States won their semifinal matches yesterday and will meet today in the singles final of the Gunze World tournament in Tokyo. In men's...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TENNIS Sabatini to Meet Grossman: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and Ann Grossman of the United States won their semifinal matches yesterday and will meet today in the singles final of the Gunze World tournament in Tokyo. In men's play, Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the Wimbledon champion, withdrew from his semifinal against Jaime Yzaga of Peru after bruising his knee when he tripped over his racquet.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 32, approved legislation today to curb imports of textiles and apparel.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 32, approved legislation today to curb imports of textiles and apparel.

headline.main: Senate Votes Import Curbs On Apparel but Veto Looms

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: A Dutch civil servant with a dry sense of humor and an endless supply of patience was in bed with the flu in Geneva when leaders of the world's seven major industrial powers found themselves struggling to pronounce his name at the Houston...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A Dutch civil servant with a dry sense of humor and an endless supply of patience was in bed with the flu in Geneva when leaders of the world's seven major industrial powers found themselves struggling to pronounce his name at the Houston summit meeting earlier this month.

headline.main: Sudden Fame for a Compromise on Trade

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States and the European Community, failing to make progress at talks in Geneva in resolving a festering trade dispute over farm subsidies, suspended negotiations today for a month.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The United States and the European Community, failing to make progress at talks in Geneva in resolving a festering trade dispute over farm subsidies, suspended negotiations today for a month.

headline.main: Stalled Geneva Farm Talks Are Suspended for a Month

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: Four days of global trade talks ended on a sour note today, with developing countries accusing rich nations of jeopardizing world commerce.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Four days of global trade talks ended on a sour note today, with developing countries accusing rich nations of jeopardizing world commerce.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Seeking to continue to pick up the kind of international experience members of the United States national team crave, Tab Ramos has signed a one-year professional contract with Figueres, a Second Division club in Spain. The announcement was...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Seeking to continue to pick up the kind of international experience members of the United States national team crave, Tab Ramos has signed a one-year professional contract with Figueres, a Second Division club in Spain. The announcement was made yesterday by the United States Soccer Federation.

docs.snippet: LEAD: For the last four years, the Israeli Foreign Ministry and a Jerusalem radio studio have run a covert program in which radio reporters were hired by the studio and given Government guidance on what they should report to radio stations around the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For the last four years, the Israeli Foreign Ministry and a Jerusalem radio studio have run a covert program in which radio reporters were hired by the studio and given Government guidance on what they should report to radio stations around the world, participants in the program and other Government officials say.

headline.main: Radio Freelancers in Israel Paid By Government-Supported Studio

byline.original: By JOEL BRINKLEY with SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a textile bill that would impose a vicious cost on U.S. consumers, violate existing American trade agreements and undermine international trade talks. Three big strikes, yet the House is poised to approve...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a textile bill that would impose a vicious cost on U.S. consumers, violate existing American trade agreements and undermine international trade talks. Three big strikes, yet the House is poised to approve similar legislation, perhaps this week.
